messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 47 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Fourier growth of structured ğ”½â‚‚-polynomials and applications

Paper Abstract: Abstract We analyze the Fourier growth, i.e. the L1subscriptğ¿1L_{1} Fourier weight at level kğ‘˜k (denoted L1,ksubscriptğ¿1ğ‘˜L_{1,k}), of various well-studied classes of â€œstructuredâ€ ğ”½2subscriptğ”½2\mathbbm{F}_{2}-polynomials. This study is motivated by applications in pseudorandomness, in particular recent results and conjectures due to [CHHL19, CHLT19, CGL+20] which show that upper bounds on Fourier growth (even at level k=2ğ‘˜2k=2) give unconditional pseudorandom generators. Our main structural results on Fourier growth are as follows: â€¢ We show that any symmetric degree-dğ‘‘d ğ”½2subscriptğ”½2\mathbbm{F}_{2}-polynomial pğ‘p has L1,kâ€‹(p)â‰¤ğğ«[p=1]â‹…Oâ€‹(d)ksubscriptğ¿1ğ‘˜ğ‘ğğ«â‹…delimited-[]ğ‘1ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘‘ğ‘˜L_{1,k}(p)\leq\mathop{\bf Pr\/}[p=1]\cdot O(d)^{k}, and this is tight for any constant kğ‘˜k. This quadratically strengthens an earlier bound that was implicit in [RSV13]. â€¢ We show that any read-Î”Î”\Delta degree-dğ‘‘d ğ”½2subscriptğ”½2\mathbbm{F}_{2}-polynomial pğ‘p has L1,kâ€‹(p)â‰¤ğğ«[p=1]â‹…(kâ€‹Î”â€‹d)Oâ€‹(k)subscriptğ¿1ğ‘˜ğ‘ğğ«â‹…delimited-[]ğ‘1superscriptğ‘˜Î”ğ‘‘ğ‘‚ğ‘˜L_{1,k}(p)\leq\mathop{\bf Pr\/}[p=1]\cdot(k\Delta d)^{O(k)}. â€¢ We establish a composition theorem which gives L1,ksubscriptğ¿1ğ‘˜L_{1,k} bounds on disjoint compositions of functions that are closed under restrictions and admit L1,ksubscriptğ¿1ğ‘˜L_{1,k} bounds. Finally, we apply the above structural results to obtain new unconditional pseudorandom generators and new correlation bounds for various classes of ğ”½2subscriptğ”½2\mathbbm{F}_{2}-polynomials.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 47 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 47"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Symmetric polynomials over â„¤m and simultaneous communication protocols",
        "Random low-degree polynomials are hard to approximate",
        "Bounded independence versus symmetric tests",
        "K-forrelation optimally separates quantum and classical query complexity",
        "An inequality for the fourier spectrum of parity decision trees",
        "Pseudorandom bits for polynomials",
        "Fractional Pseudorandom Generators from Any Fourier Level",
        "Pseudorandom generators from polarizing random walks",
        "Pseudorandom generators from the second Fourier level and applications to AC0 with parity gates",
        "Improved pseudorandomness for unordered branching programs through local monotonicity",
        "Almost-everywhere circuit lower bounds from non-trivial derandomization",
        "Tight changâ€™s-lemma-type bounds for boolean functions",
        "Expander random walks: A fourier-analytic approach",
        "Log-seed pseudorandom generators via iterated restrictions",
        "On beating the hybrid argument",
        "Block-symmetric polynomials correlate with parity better than symmetric",
        "Quantum Versus Randomized Communication Complexity, with Efficient Players",
        "Lower bounds for XOR of forrelations",
        "Degree and sensitivity: tails of two distributions",
        "The distribution of polynomials over finite fields, with applications to the Gowers norms",
        "Fourier Growth of Parity Decision Trees",
        "Approximating the number of zeroes of a GF[2] polynomial",
        "Fourier bounds and pseudorandom generators for product tests",
        "Inverse conjecture for the Gowers norm is false",
        "Unconditional pseudorandom generators for low-degree polynomials",
        "More on bounded independence plus noise: pseudorandom generators for read-once polynomials",
        "An O(nloglogn) learning algorithm for DNF under the uniform distribution",
        "Pseudorandom generators for width-3 branching programs",
        "Pseudorandom generators for space-bounded computation",
        "Analysis of Boolean Functions",
        "NIST handbook of mathematical functions hardback and CD-ROM",
        "Learning monotone decision trees in polynomial time",
        "Lower bounds on the dimension of schemes of bounded depth in a complete basis containing the logical addition function",
        "Pseudorandomness for regular branching programs via fourier analysis",
        "Oracle separation of BQP and PH",
        "Algebraic methods in the theory of lower bounds for boolean circuit complexity",
        "An Optimal Separation of Randomized and Quantum Query Complexity",
        "Improved pseudorandom generators from pseudorandom multi-switching lemmas",
        "Pseudorandomness for read-k DNF formulas",
        "Tight bounds on the Fourier spectrum of AC0",
        "Towards optimal separations between quantum and randomized query complexities",
        "On the power of small-depth computation",
        "The sum of d small-bias generators fools polynomials of degree d",
        "Challenges in computational lower bounds",
        "Fourier conjectures, correlation bounds, and majority",
        "New lower bounds for probabilistic degree and AC0 with parity gates",
        "Kravchuk polynomials"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 47 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Fourier growth of structured ğ”½â‚‚-polynomials and applications, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
